title.narrative: ACCESS TO HIV CARE AND TREATMENT SERVICES

description.narrative: By 2020, health care providers are able to identify, treat and retain in care children and adolescents living with HIV in UNICEF- supported districts., which contributes to Treatment And Care Of Children Living With Hiv, Treatment And Care Of Children Living With Hiv (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: School-age children, particularly girls and those in vulnerable regions, have access to quality basic education, including in emergency situations.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2020, health care providers are able to identify, treat and retain in care children and adolescents living with HIV in UNICEF-supported districts.

description.narrative: The program target was to offer ART to at least 80% of pregnant/breastfeeding women, children and adolescents living with HIV. UNICEF extended its support from 10 to 55 districts from the second semester of 2020. However, COVID-19 undermined planning and scale-up processes. Currently, ART is progressively decentralised from hospitals to primary health care facilities through task-shifting and task-sharing to nurses and community stakeholders. By October 2021, 6,565 out of 18,081 HIV+ children and adolescents were identified and put on ART, leading to a coveragerate of36%. | Status:Partially met | As-of Date:02/02/2022
